title: Mastering Posing, Focal Length, and Perspective in Photography
summary: Photographer Lindsay Adler explains the critical relationship between body posing, focal length, and perspective. She demonstrates how to use distance and lens choice to manipulate proportions, emphasizing or downplaying specific features to flatter the subject.

steps.action: Utilize the proximity principle: position body parts closer to the camera to make them appear larger, or further away to make them appear smaller.
Adjust camera angle to change perspective. Shoot from a higher angle to emphasize the face/chest, or a lower angle to elongate the body and emphasize height.
Select focal length to control distortion. Use wide-angle lenses close to the subject to exaggerate size differences (e.g., making a hand look huge).
Use a longer focal length and increase distance from the subject to compress perspective and flatten features, making proportions look more even.

key_takeaways: Posing is not just body position; it relies on focal length and perspective.
Whatever is closest to the camera appears largest.
Wide-angle lenses exaggerate distance and size; long lenses compress and flatten perspective.
Camera height determines which part of the body is closest to the lens, altering perceived proportions.
